FlavourText.SourceString: A slightly weathered sign with ornamental carvings and a welcoming script.

BodyText.SourceString:
Welcome to the Great Caoivish capital of Sunhaven.

There comes a time when even our wise father Sun craves hearth and home. 

- Iain Callahan.

FlavourText.SourceString: A corpse who, by the look of him, has been dead for quite some time.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>You pick through his satchel for supplies, careful not to disturb the bones. In it, you find naught but a letter. It looks ready to crumble. With the back of your hand, you brush flecks of snow off the envelope, and inch the letter out just enough to read it while kneeling. </>

Those southron bastards actually had the balls to march. We'd heard they might be buggered enough make a move, the cunts, but even with all I’d seen, I wouldn't have thought they’d had the sacks for it. Those fucking greencoats couldn't keep their dicks tied up and just had to march north.

Some good that giant bloody wall did. I pissed on it before the boys and I trucked back to Sunhaven. Those pricks're coming, though. Gather the mules and get the girls to Whedon's Row. Stars take me if we can't hold here. 

Love, Uncle Sean.

FlavourText.SourceString: You pluck a letter from amongst a smattering of papers and stationery.

BodyText.SourceString:
By week’s end, they’ll be setting charges on that bridge to the north. To have spent our entire lives here just to be left behind. Mercy, indeed. Forgive my harsh words then, Carol—you’ve honoured our name in your own way. It was a mistake to have mistrusted you more than these walls. They have become our prison, our shame. 

<RichText.Italic12>Under the letter, there’s a paycheck from the NSRF to the same addressee.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: The statue of Callhan towers over you. You feel welcomed by his outstretched hand.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>There's a plaque. Most of the text is legible.</>

Caoiva's founder and first Archon, Iain Callahan, united the land with the promise of riches, safety, and bountiful harvest. 

It was with his left hand that he offered our foes gifts of friendship, alliance and protection.

FlavourText.SourceString: The statue is destroyed and defaced. The sight is grisly and brings little comfort.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>The plaque on the statue is charred and worn, but you can make out some of the text.</>

…instilled fear with his right hand. 

With it he commanded vast armies and raised his shield for the good of all… 

<RichText.Italic12>The rest is obscured.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: You find the notes of an out-of-sorts doctor. Most of them are medical charts, diagnoses and random markings. However, one record seems out of place.

BodyText.SourceString:
There’s not much left to be done, I think. ‘Oh, it’ll be fine, Roger,’ they all said. I ain’t no doctor and told ‘em that the day they put me here. All we have’re these bloody books to work from, and that’s simply not enough. Only help are crippled bastards who had no chance of seeing the front. Just the other day, got a report about some wounded men down south. These were folk they say might see another day, so’s we sent out a dispatch. Blasted truck never made it. 

I worry I’ve developed a martyr complex, killing meself to try to help those doomed the day they were born. Perhaps we all are. Perhaps I’m doomed to this damned orphanage. Irony is, it’s kids here that die the most. Suppose I tried, ey.
The Salt Farms

FlavourText.SourceString: Kneeling over the ice, you peer into the frigid water.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>There’s a chain of pallid blue corpses. Your eyes dart from one to the next, and you can’t shake the feeling that they’re climbing over one another desperate to reach the surface. </>

<RichText.Italic12>A pang of terror runs through your spine, and you blink the vision away. They are still, frozen and lost. To be reminded of this brings you no comfort.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: Slick with dirt and damp, you find a pile of letters mingling amongst a smattering of small parts, tools and different calibres of bullets. One of the letters illuminates what this intrepid engineer might have been up to.

BodyText.SourceString:
The mechanism won’t fire quick enough to make a difference. It overheats and I can’t seem to get the balance right. Everytime I try to hit the target it flails about wildly. Three tripods I’ve broken, Jonathan, three! How’d they manage it? Maybe we’ll never know. 

I must have burned my skin to bone about as many times as I’ve broken fingers. These blasted old rifles… maybe it’s time to seek out new materials. New tools. I fear I may not be successful out here in the wetlands. Let me tell you, those dreadful birds never shut up!

If you have any thoughts, please write back in a hurry. 

<RichText.Italic12>He signs off with only, ‘Your dear friend.’</>

FlavourText.SourceString: The grisly sight of a dead bird lies before you. Yet, depsite your own logical internal protests, you decide to take a closer look.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>At first, what you take for a dead bird is in fact, a carcass stuffed with straw and leaves. Its feathers and eyes have been carefully reconstructed.</>

<RichText.Italic12>What a morbid display.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: A putrid stench fills the air. You nearly retch, but steel yourself and swallow it back. The source of the smell is clear; a skeletal corpse lay against the wall. A small rock is entangled between bony fingers.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>Your eyes flit to something peculiar behind him. The wall near the corpse is plastered with mad scrawlings.</>

Hah. I figured out what none could. Stupid smugglers. Stupid me, I guess. They found me, and I’m sure you figured out what happened.

There’s another wall, you must know. Nothing less than a tank will crack it, and even then, I’m not sure that would do it. Maybe with enough force. 

Enough . . . What is enough?

It’s dark now. Light flickers. Out of matches. Cold. Hungry. The monsters. Did I deserve this?

FlavourText.SourceString: You find a somber note nailed to the tree.

BodyText.SourceString:
This war—why keep fighting it? What are we fighting for? I won't anymore. Not now, not after Jackson— 

<RichText.Italic12>There's a smear of ink between lines.</>

We've stood side by side since we were children. Trained together for years on, only to watch him put a bullet in his head. Everything's heavy now, I am underwater, I can't breathe. It's been days, and I'm still here. Getting hungry, haven’t eaten in days. But, I can't leave him. He fears the night. What would he do without me? Besides, I just want to stare out into the sea. At least I'll always have that, eh, Jackson?

<RichText.Italic12>There are two ragged sunflowers carved into the bark.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: A sign with directions to various locations in the region.

BodyText.SourceString:
↑ Tuatha Watchpost. 

<RichText.Italic12>Someone scratched in some illegible letters. It's hard to tell what it means.</>

→ Saltbrook Channel.

↑ Vulpine Watch.

FlavourText.SourceString: What might have once been a fitting memorial to a lost war hero is now in shambles before you, the plaque vandalised and defaced.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>You can only make out a couple of letters from the inscription underneath,</> "u, a, n, w, v,” <RichText.Italic12>and what is clearly the word the word</> “us.” <RichText.Italic12>The rest has been painted over with slurs and vulgar imagery.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: It appears that someone lived in this remote location.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>Signs of life are scattered all over the rocks. The remnants of a makeshift shelter, a well-used firepit, animal carcasses and a beat-up old boat. </>

FlavourText.SourceString: Excerpt from a letter addressed to someone named Juno.

BodyText.SourceString:
...I wish they had just cooled their trade expansion. I wish they would have left well enough alone and stayed hidden in their little mountain fortress. Now Maro, she... well, I think it's all about pride at this point but she assures us it’s securing our legacy. And yet she has so many mice whispering in her ears, does she even know what's truth? 

How much longer do we let this continue? What's even left to fight for? Love, please write back to me. I must know that you’re safe. I'm leaving Terra as soon as is feasible. It'll be some time before I make it back to Kálokai but there's a barge coming along on which I mean to stow away. 

This cock of a war, I yearn for you to see its end; I’m afraid I will not be so lucky. The lad who carried my letter, he’s trustworthy. He'll get whatever you entrust with him back to me. He knows the plan. 

Please, enjoy the wine, I nearly died for it. 

Kisses,

Christos

<RichText.Italic12>You guess that the letter never made it to Juno.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: A table covered in old books and papers.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>Standing out with its red and blue binding is a book detailing the journeys and follies of an ancient foreign sea god.</>

<RichText.Italic12>Scattered around the book are several tattered yet undelivered letters. You suspect most were intended to reassure loved ones about the state of the war. </>

FlavourText.SourceString: A journal left behind by a deserting soldier.

BodyText.SourceString:
I’ve decided to leave a trail with the hope it might wind up in the hands of those starting to question all of this. To reach those who feel hopeless or afraid. If my words find you, know this: you can escape. 

I left this war as a high ranking member of the Swords of Maro. I promise, this is not in jest. It was heartbreaking. That company was all I had. To me, they’re family. Even today, I’d die for any one of them. But I learned there is life outside of war. You’ll soon find it too. 

On my travels, a man taught me some Velian history. Our once great country struck a deal with Mesea hundreds of years ago. Did you know we once had a king? A Kingdom? The Caoivish are no better. Their greed is what forced us Velians into desperation. Their wall. Their need for control. 

I'm not interested in fighting a war of opportunity. Are you?

I’ve met a girl. And, I know what you’ll try to tell me. 

But what if? Why not? I’d like a life with her. A simple one, away from war. Would you turn down warmth in your bed? A fire to come home to? A home at all? It’s a risk worth taking. 

We're headed north to Nicnevin. It’s through rough terrain where, hopefully we won't be followed. We mean to take the pass through Morgen's Crossing. A bit of an inside joke so we didn’t want to miss it.

If you arrive at the Crossing, you may find us and I that hope you do. Know that you have friends in the north. 

Follow the stars.

FlavourText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>A makeshift grave marker. Something is carved in the wood.</>

BodyText.SourceString: Beru

FlavourText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>A makeshift grave marker. Something is carved in the wood.</>

BodyText.SourceString: Owen

FlavourText.SourceString: Along the cave wall, you spot a series of organized etches on either side of a separating line.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>The left side has thirty-four and the right has thirty-one. A few in the middle are scuffed out. </>

<RichText.Italic12>You suspect it was used to count days or to tally something.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: Inside a tent, you find a handful of notes once passed between two soldiers. It takes a moment, but you manage to piece them together.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Regular12.Green>Oh, come on, Saoirse! Tanks don’t count for two!</>

<RichText.Regular12.Orange>Yes, you shit, they do. Oh, enough with the look. It was a bloody tank!</>

<RichText.Italic12>Some words are scratched out.</>

<RichText.Regular12.Green>Ugh. It’s a game of body count. You’d get a point If you’d nicked the crew. It was a parked tank, you cheat.</>

<RichText.Italic12>Several arrows point to the word nothing which is emphasised by scratchy underlines.</>

<RichText.Regular12.Orange>How is that fair? So you’re telling me, you can count an injured Collie and it’s okay?</>

<RichText.Regular12.Green>Fine. You get one point. But you need to stop cheating Cara, otherwise this shitty game is no fun.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: Volume 2 of a magazine called “Inner Haven.”

BodyText.SourceString:
...and let’s not forget <RichText.Bold12.Colonial>Legate Thea Maro.</>

She was a visionary. None could have imagined how well she’d live up to and perhaps surpass her great grandfather's legacy. Naysayers and <RichText.Italic12>experts</> in the senate claimed that Warden inner defences were impenetrable, a folly to pursue. Yet, our glorious commander proved them wrong with her unconventional strategies and radical tactics. 

To no surprise, she would go on to be awarded a seat on the high council representing Veli for her valor and bravery. It stunned the republic when Maro refused, opting instead to remain on the battlefield. 

All of Mesea—and Veli most of all—should feel blessed to have such a dedicated and capable commander leading the Colonial Legions toward our inevitable victory.

<RichText.Bold12.Colonial>For The End, Is Our Glory.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: A tent that is clearly abandoned, with few signs of life.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>Inside, there is nothing but dirt and debris. The tent is falling over and, frankly, seems like it’s been standing a long time.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: On the ground you find a Colonial satchel amidst a makeshift shelter.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>The surroundings show signs of a minor scuffle. Seems the bag was dropped in the altercation; six fine wooden figures spill out across the stone tiles. There’s a swordsman, horseman, a general, a civilian, a pikeman and an archer.</>

<RichText.Italic12>You get the impression they were used in some kind of game.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: Excerpt from a mouldy letter.

BodyText.SourceString:
...they fled through an old mine. 

Nothing in there but iron. Though, I heard some of the boys mention gold below sea level. Suppose you'd want to be informed if we’d found anything valuable. 

The island fell quickly, for what it’s worth, but this brutish woman managed to escape. She led at least a dozen refugees through far side of the mine. Seems the workers had built a hidden alcove oceanside and loaded up supplies for months. 

We're still not sure where they got the boats, however. Perhaps she cut a deal with those petty smugglers, the Hanged Men. Once they'd pushed off, the damned rebels collapsed the mine with explosives. Unfortunately, we couldn’t cut them off. Credit to them, it was a well laid out plan. 

We'll send word to our men at the coastline to keep an eye out.
<RichText.Italic12>This pit looks like it was set up for a fire, but never lit.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: You find a ragged journal opened to the last entry.

BodyText.SourceString:
Morgan escaped and stowed away on a ship headed for Westgate. She said from there she would steal a truck on her way north through the Heartlands. 

On and on she went, talking about getting a ship and backup and saving us — Blah blah. I didn't believe her. In fact, I was sure she'd die on her way out. Boyo I was wrong.

She pulled a knife from this dumb Collie's belt, slit his throat and gutted the wanker next to him. It was like watching a bloody dance. After they fell, she scooped up a rifle and hid in the back of a truck. The numpty waved at me from behind a few crates. After all that nonsense, I'm not so sure she <RichText.Italic12>is</> a liar, after all.

Maybe I stand a chance to get off this wretched island before I croak.

FlavourText.SourceString: A cairn that marks a grave of sorts.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>There’s a scrap metal nameplate fastened to the front with something carved into it.</>

Here lyes Church. 
He wuz a good boy. 
An flufy 2.

FlavourText.SourceString: Volume 1 of a magazine called “Inner Haven.”

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Bold12.Colonial>…Legate Silas Maro</> was the first to walk the smoking remains of the Breach. Following his cowardly assassination at the battle for Sunhaven, it was his descendant <RichText.Bold12.Colonial>Thea Maro</> who led our Legions into the hostile north. 

Groomed from birth, an expert tactician with exceptional natural gifts, Thea exercised swift and decisive leadership. It was her will that brought us to the heart of Caoiva.

Maro offered the northerners peace, on the condition of joining our great republic. Such a distinction would have been an honour, yet they spit in our faces and call us dogs. If only they'd laid down their arms, we may have avoided generations of bloodshed.

<RichText.Bold12.Colonial>For The End, Is Our Glory.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: Just an old, empty flask.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>It hasn't rusted, so you hold onto it. Just in case.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: At first glance, it appears to be a simple book. As you shift it between your hands, you feel something clanking around inside.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>You tap it. It’s hollow.</>

<RichText.Italic12>Inside you find a hole carved out between the pages, revealing a generous amount of dried jerky fastened with cedar twine. It smells delicious, but you know it’s worth too much to simply eat. Though, your hunger might betray you.</>

<RichText.Italic12>It’s been ages since you’ve smelled decent meat.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: A sun-bleached human skeleton lies on the deck.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>The bones have been picked clean. You suspect it might have been carrion birds or some kind of wild animal. Or both. Either way, a rough way to go.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: An old, rickety outhouse.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>A sign on the privy reads, "Occupied."</>

FlavourText.SourceString: Amongst the rubble you find a large map of Caoiva laid across a table. It’s wine-stained and torn.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>The map is wine-stained and torn.</>

<RichText.Italic12>Despite the damage, you notice something peculiar. Various locations are marked by a black X.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: What appears to be a written radio transcript of a call between a child and his deployed father.

BodyText.SourceString:
Father - Why do we still grow flowers? 

Child - to remember a time before war—before me.  

F - And before I was born, and my father, and his father before him.  

C - How do we know there was a time like that.  

F - We trust our fathers and our mothers. We know that, a long time ago, there was a time of peace. Here in the old Swan, we’ve always brought sunflowers to the Fengari Church. Your grandad said it was so we could surround the darkness with light. To hold onto hope for a future. That way, the light can never to be snuffed out.

<RichText.Italic12>The transcript continues, but you feel you’ve intruded enough.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: A small grave.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>You get the impression it’s not very deep and was dug hastily. Carved into a wooden marker is only a name, “Markos.”</>

FlavourText.SourceString: A note written in hasty scrawlings.

BodyText.SourceString:
We ran out of barrels for the bodies. At this point, we should light a bloody pyre. 

I understand that a pyre would signal our position for miles, but the bastards already know we’re here, why play this game with fate? If you won’t concede, then we should at least dump them into that dreadful pit. It stinks plenty already and might mask the decay.

But, when the time comes, we need to burn the dead so as not to invite disease.

FlavourText.SourceString: A granite headstone with an unusual amount of care and attention put to the nameplate carving.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>Here lies Dorian Grivas.</>

<RichText.Italic12>Loving mother of three, loyal wife, fierce competitor, and valued Colonial.</>

<RichText.Italic12>Born in Katoma, Dorian ranked highest amongst her legion, with an excess of two hundred confirmed kills and twenty-five successful operations, she was a standout soldier who modelled exemplary leadership skills.</>

<RichText.Italic12>She will be missed.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: You find a sealed, unsent letter. Without thinking, you tear it open.

BodyText.SourceString:
Sir, we were able to cut them off from the rear, it was much easier than anticipated. This region had been barren aside from a few civilians and children, most of whom fled once we took Eristown. 

The daft Collies never guess we’d be coming. Recon moved in with the cover of night, and now their sentries are worm food. I heard some even begged like the dogs they are! Can you believe that? Never in my life have I seen such a thing with my own eyes. A Collie, begging. The bastards are getting soft.

Cpt. Brightwen

FlavourText.SourceString: You find a few bottles, some dice, and an unsealed letter.

BodyText.SourceString:
I don’t know what’s happened here, Prefect. 

I’m doing my best to make sense of the situation. It’s not like Wardens to peek south of their blasted wall. It seems we’ve rattled the wasp’s nest and they’ve seen fit to sting us for it. Tell the Legate we believe they intend to vie for control of the March to open up a southern checkpoint. 

We can’t afford them a foothold this far south and must secure the road ourselves. Get reinforcements up here so we can drive out these coat-tailed whoresons.

FlavourText.SourceString: An old, abandoned tent.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>Inside, the tent smells quite nice. There are finely crafted down pillows and a fur blanket. You suspect they were pillaged from nearby houses.  </>

FlavourText.SourceString: An old, abandoned tent.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>Your nostrils fill with the stench of alcohol and body odour.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: You find a note on the back of a recruitment poster.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>Everything is written in erratic cursive. </>

If one of you Collie fuckers see this, consider it a warning. I'm coming for you, I see you now. 

Watch your back, dogs. 

- M

FlavourText.SourceString: You find a note on the back of a recruitment poster.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>A poster depicting a group of soldiers in blue standing side by side bearing shields before a mountain range. They tower over a pile of bloodied corpses in drab.</>

<RichText.regular12.Warden>These are our streets. These are our people, these are our lands, stand up and join the Hands.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: You’ve stumbled upon what appears to be an abandoned workshop.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>The table is covered in old documents. While most are irrelevant, you notice a shipping manifest stamped with the letters NSRF. </>

<RichText.Italic12>It lists supplies recovered after skirmishes in the area and names of a salvage detachment, their contributions, and payments for an operation. </>

<RichText.Italic12>One name stands out: Carol Gough-Mercy.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: Inside the tent are two small bedrolls and a burnt out lantern.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>Next to the lantern are piles of sticks pressed together to form two dozen hexagons sitting on top of flattened birch bark. Inside the hexagons are whittled wooden figures. Each one seems to represent something different, a rider on horseback, an archer, a wagon, etc. Some are knocked over on the outside the grid.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: There's a wide assortment of books.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>Many of these books were thought to have been lost in the great wars. </>

<RichText.Italic12>You guess someone was trying to keep an archive.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: Aged casks of wine.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>Someone must have smuggled these into the Heartlands.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: This fire pit appears to be well-used.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>There’s nothing but charred bits of wood in the base of the pit.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: Volume 12 of a magazine called “Inner Haven.”

BodyText.SourceString:
...the people of the north are so arrogant, they even name cities after themselves. Just look how much they spend on paltry trifles like tacky statues and lifeless paintings. 

They're blind to our world. Will they even see us when the Colonial Legion storm their walls like thunder. For so long, they’ve looked down on us, but we'll be the ones standing tall. 

All they'll see is the dirt we shovel over their eyes.

FlavourText.SourceString: A dented tin tobacco case.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>Inside there’s a hand-crafted pipe alongside preserved tobacco wrapped in wax paper. There's a note.</>

Here's a sample of the Tobacco. Smuggled it out of the farm complexes southeast by Therízo. You Caoivish have never smoked the likes of this, I promise you. If you’re hankering for more, fill the case with some of that jerky from the Fisherman's Row. Leave it at the fort. Once it’s found, I’ll send a lad out to set up a meet.

FlavourText.SourceString: Buried in the sand, you find a bedroll and rucksack, the bag sunbleached, the roll teeming with tiny crabs.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>You rifle through the abandoned gear looking for something useful but find only a tattered notebook.</>

<RichText.Italic12>It’s filled with indiscernible drawings of what appear to be maps, each marked with an X. Some are paired with another strange symbol. Scrawlings fill the blanks, but you can only make out one paragraph near a map you recognize as the Vale.</>

. . . The Hanged Men, it must be them. Who else? It yields to nothing I’ve tried thus far. Small arms are useless. We’ve tried setting a hefty charge, and the damn thing hardly creaked. If we could only find something from before. 

Those made in the ways of old, they had more kick. Yes. That crater, to this day I’ve not seen another like it. Find them, yes. A hefty payload, a hefty treasure.

FlavourText.SourceString: A simple sign.

BodyText.SourceString: Welcome to the Olde Louster Farm.

FlavourText.SourceString: In the field ahead, you spot several ominous-looking stakes driven into the ground.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>As you approach the stakes something ancient weighs down on you. The wood has rotted and splintered, and the bones of the dead can hardly be recognized as human. It’s no wonder the Hanged Men have taken it for their sigil in defiance of fate.</>

<RichText.Italic12>The field around you, now overgrown and wild, was once the staging ground for an ancient battle. The horrors committed here have been committed before and will be again.</>

<RichText.Italic12>You laugh at the irony of it all. Why did these men die in such a grisly fashion, if, after all this time, war rages on?</>

FlavourText.SourceString: You’ve found the journal of First Command, Legatus Alekos Dimas.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>It appears to be original, but—after some inspection—come to terms with the fact that it’s a copy. Pages have been removed, that alone is quite the oddity. One sheet is folded over.</>

<RichText.Regular12.Beige>21 Temple, 783.</>

Those bastards in the Senate. All this anger, with no place to air grievances, save these trusted pages. How could they think to retire me? With so much to be done. So much left on the table. After all, I’ve done for them, for Mesea, in Aktío and now Veli.

Do these past decades mean nothing? Does standing shoulder-to-shoulder with Silas Maro in the ruin of that dreadful wall mean nothing? No. Early retirement is my reward. And for what purpose? Shall I retreat to the country, ripen in some crumbling estate, clutching my rifle like a child? This is not how I end.

FlavourText.SourceString: By all accounts, you’ve found a normal, old, rusted shovel. But then, you pull a tiny piece of paper that was hidden in the metal frame.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>Carefully, you unfold it to find a poem, maybe a song.</>

They tell us to stand, 
So we stand.
They tell us to fight,
So we fight.
They tell us to dig.

And we dig our graves.
For the end of the war,
We will not see. 
For there is no end,
When the world’s gone to hell.

They feed us the dirt,
So we eat it smiling.
They arm us with shovels,
So we dig their trenches.
They hand us our guts,
So we can shove them back in.

FlavourText.SourceString: You stumble upon a rusted old toolbox and a clipboard with loose documents.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>A lot of it is remarkably well-preserved. The notes are filled with architectural sketches and engineering drafts, none of which you can make sense of. </>

<RichText.Italic12>Notes fill the margins, but only one, in particular, catches your interest.</>

The internal vaults should and will hold fast against conventional methods. It would take a concentrated force to break through, considering it’s been lined with slabs and reinforced with braided metals.

Ordinary munitions would do little more than chip the concrete. Only those versed in proper demolitions would have a chance at breaking through. Of those, there aren’t many these days.

Our take should stay safe. Well, at least for a time.

FlavourText.SourceString: An opened letter sits on the table.

BodyText.SourceString:
Saints be damned, The Moors? 

Where in the hell is that? You’re being deployed to some to some backwoods town? Why do they call it that anyway? It’s probably frozen most of the year, who’s bringing boats? 

I wish you could answer me as I write but I know it’ll be some time, maybe years before I hear back. They’re making me a prosthetic metal leg and once I learn to walk properly, they might send me back out. I’m excited. Feels like I just got started when I got caught by that mine. 

The break has been… fine, but like you said back when it happened, “You are Mesean, your blood is gunpowder, trenches are your home, the dirt your soft downy pillow. Life is too short to waste working the fields or toiling away at a machine belt.” 

Then you said something crass about my mother and that’s where my memory gets fuzzy. Once I get back out there, you bet your ass I owe you a stiff drink.

FlavourText.SourceString: There’s a barrel, some rags, and a pot frozen over with ice.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>You guess that the pot was used to heat up the water and then wash dirt from the trenches.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: An old transcript of what was presumably a radio conversation.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.regular12.green>Whedon’s Row is a goddamned mountain fortress. Have you been there? No. Well, I have.</>

<RichText.regular12.orange>Can we not assault from the sea? It’s my understanding that there’s a wide open shore. </>

<RichText.regular12.green>Do not underestimate the Caoivish, Consul. If you think that they haven’t adequately prepared for this, you’d be mistaken. </>

<RichText.regular12.orange>Damn, they’re like roaches. What do you suggest then, Commander? </>

<RichText.regular12.green>We should leave them to their mountains! There’s no value in Whedon’s Row. We’ll starve them out and they are forced to emerge, Caoiva will be Mesean soil.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: A note to a Colonial squad leader.

BodyText.SourceString:
They didn’t want to say this over the radio, someone might be listening. Command is going to spend the resources and drop a company up north to secure the route to Nicnevin. 

If the Caoivish Wardens make allies out of them, that would be bad news for us. But if we cut off the pass, we can stop that from happening. Or better yet, discredit them. They aren’t known to make deals on a whim.

FlavourText.SourceString: There’s a book with a mark carved into the cover that looks like a star.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>Opening it reveals a letter addressed to someone named Ciara.</>

You said you would meet me here and we’d travel north to take the long route to Morgen’s Crossing. Don’t you remember? People are gathering there.

I’ve been waiting for days, and still, you haven’t arrived. Combat is breaking out in this region. I can’t wait any longer. I’ll try to wait in Morgen’s Crossing. Hopefully the fighting doesn’t make it that far. It doesn’t help matters that I’ve got a target on my back from both sides.

FlavourText.SourceString: It’s cold here.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>You adjust your jacket and wipe the snow from your trousers. Tiny crystals of ice have formed on the tips of your eyelashes. When you blink, it causes your eyelids to freeze together for a moment. You’re tired and want to sleep, but you know that the sleep never comes.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: A book chronicling the history and accomplishments of Callahan and his elite military unit called “The Hands”

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>Some chapters detail how he was able to unite warring clans, how they staved off northern invaders, brought prosperity and hope to Caoiva and laid out the foundations of the Bulwark to the south.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: A battered, rusty old officer’s sabre.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>There’s an inscription on the blade. “Gough-Mercy.” </>

<RichText.Italic12>A shame to see such exquisite craftsmanship left to rust.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: You’ve stumbled upon what appears to be some form of meat processing facility.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>Inside the cylinders, you see the remains of—as far as you can tell—small birds, oils, and a wide variety of salts and spices.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: There’s some intriguing poetry on a journal page marked by a folded corner.

BodyText.SourceString:
Eagles fly, but only beasts takes the sun; 

The sands of time have turned to flies. 

It's no gift, but a garish curse, the machine always seems to run. 

Who tells tall tales? it is not I, my brethren are plump with lies. 

Why shoot the messenger?

But I know you will, Callahan always takes my gun.

FlavourText.SourceString: There is chaos all around you.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>Blood still stains the frozen earth and viscera is splattered about.</>

<RichText.Italic12>The blood has long since dried, the corpses frozen for many moons, yet curiously, the coals in the fire still smoulder. </>

<RichText.Italic12>Almost as if someone had spent time here recently.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: A standard-issue Loughcaster rifle.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>The name, "Cara" is carved into the trigger guard. </>

<RichText.Italic12>Small cuts are marked into the stock. This rifle cannot be cleaned. This rifle cannot be loaded. This rifle will not fire. It's too light. Blood pours out from the barrel when the trigger is squeezed. </>

<RichText.Italic12>You feel it must be cursed and aren't sure why you still carry it.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: An abandoned fire pit.

BodyText.SourceString: The coals are still hot.

FlavourText.SourceString: You find part of a very old, mouldy journal. You casually flip through and stop on a random page.

BodyText.SourceString:
The locals have told me a tall tale of a man they will only refer to as the ‘Dullahan.’ They say he’s some spirit or other who wanders the sea with flames where his head should be, beaming like a lantern. 

Some say he rides on horseback, a blood red mare with its head flayed, exposing polished bone. Apparently, his ship, The Burgundi, was stranded in the north filled with cavalrymen and a cargo hold filled with horses and other livestock...

FlavourText.SourceString: A letter between Colonial remote operations leaders.

BodyText.SourceString:
There’s this crusty old captain in the lighthouse, anytime we get near he lets loose with a shotgun. I’ve lost three men, but honestly, he’s got it held pretty well. The lads are building a pyre. We’re going to try smoking him out. 

We need that lighthouse for our ships coming to port from Katoma, they don’t call these islands the Oar Breakers for nothing. If you could send a couple more hands our way, I’d appreciate it.

FlavourText.SourceString: You’ve discovered a stolen Colonial recon report.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>There’s a typed letter attached, it reads:</>

Magister, we’ve heard from our Kraunian allies out west: the Bronze Men have taken the desert at Leiloa Fa. The Senate implores us to keep contact with them. They may be drunks and rapists, but they are a powerful force with whom we wish to ensure allegiance. 

We offer them much, and they serve our interests in the west. This is a game we must play. There are whispers of resistances trickling out of the warring countries. Some refusing to fight, others refusing to provide. This is troubling. Reports from our own city-states claim total fidelity as anticipated. 

I suspect the Bronze Men along with our myriad allies, will play a part in maintaining their loyalty for generations.

FlavourText.SourceString: You find a letter from mother to son. Parts are frozen solid, others smudged and illegible.

BodyText.SourceString:
Why the Brigade of the Eight Sons? I . . . I understand fighting with the Wardens, I do. But must you fight bearing the legacy of a man who left your ancestors to die? His sons were protected, lived full and in luxury, but make no mistake, you will not if you go. 

In your last letter, you said you’d already pledged, so I know it’s too late. But we can run. We can leave this land. Find a way out. A way to live. Come home.

<RichText.Italic12>The rest is, unfortunately, lost.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: You’ve found the journal of First Command, Legatus Alekos Dimas.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>At first, you take it for an original, but soon realize it is, in fact, a copy. Some pages have been torn out, but why go through the effort to remove pages from a copy? A page is marked.</>

<RichText.Regular12.Beige>8 Cos, 782.</>

It’s a crisp morning here. I fear I’ll never grow accustomed to this northern weather. In many ways, I admire them. All these years, all they’ve built and to deal with those horrid winters . . .

My work of late has been no less frigid. These children are hopeless. If they can’t be trained they should be put to work. Yet, here I am, wasting away, drinking myself to an early grave with these whelps who can barely tell which way to hold a rifle.

I’m getting old, too old for this war, to be sure. This war that’s bellowed and cooled. I fear I’ll not see its end. A shame, as I’d hoped to see it through.

HeaderText.SourceString: A Brief History of Caoiva Vol. I

FlavourText.SourceString: You find a book titled “Volume I - A Brief History of Caoiva” and flip to a random page.

BodyText.SourceString:
Carden Callahan, the fourth son of our first Archon, Iain Callahan, took it upon his shoulders to quell the riots in Whedon’s Row. The soldiers were reluctant to support him initially, due to his lack of experience in matters of warfare.

As unrest spread southwest to Ogmaran, Callahan, leading a small force of his own men, infiltrated the town and held it without shedding a drop of blood. Deft in the art of diplomacy, his silver tongue earned him a bevy of new followers. They commemorated his leadership with a name befitting the son of a legend.

Thus, the Brigade of the Eight Sons was formed. Callahan led them into battle, proudly bearing the honour of his brothers until his death at the hands of Velian rebels.

FlavourText.SourceString: There's an old motorcycle with a Colonial logo painted on the side.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>There's a ragged 'X' Scratched through it. Underneath it, the words, "Fucking southern mechanics" are carved into the charred metal.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: Someone was bold to make camp here.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>There’s an old Caovish superstition about old fortress ruins. When they form rings, and mushrooms grow, it’s said to be a portal to another world, where strange creatures abduct those nearby, replace them and return to society. It’s all just superstitions though. At least that’s what you keep telling yourself. </>

FlavourText.SourceString: You stumble across what appears to be the chassis of an old, rundown vehicle.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>Its purpose is unknown to you and it clearly has seen better days. Trees, small plants and even flowers have overtaken what once must have been a massive vehicle.</>

<RichText.Italic12>Thoughts of the crew flash before your eyes. Images of ghosts who once piloted this beast until its engine sputtered out, only to be abandoned here, lost to a once promising frontier. They must have been some crew, you think. Taming such a monster would not have been for the faint of heart. You feel compelled to reach out and touch the damp, rusted metal only to be reminded that it is, in fact, just a dead machine.</>

<RichText.Italic12>All things must die it seems, man and machine alike.</>

<RichText.Italic12>Then, as if spurred on by your thoughts, you spot movement . . .</> 

<RichText.Italic12>Tucked inside where the driver might have been is a small next. A litter of tiny lynx stare back at you, their frightened eyes glowing in the shadow of the beast.</>

<RichText.Italic12>A smile forces itself across your face, and you tap the machine’s frame like it’s the shoulder of an old friend.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: Volume 8 of a magazine called “Inner Haven.”

BodyText.SourceString:
—and they still look to the past, to when Callahan united their people. If he was so great, and if their wealth so vast . . . well, their “wondrous” Bulwark certainly wasn't up to the task, and now—

<RichText.Italic12>The rest of the pages are mouldy and illegible.</>
<RichText.Italic12>An old setting for a fire that has been well used.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: A large stone sits at the center of a carefully constructed enclosure.

BodyText.SourceString:
Here sits the Viper's Skull, Kirknell's founding stone. 

This stone, as it sits, has done before us all, and will remain forever and beyond.

FlavourText.SourceString: While flipping through dull manuscripts, a page written in a different hand slips out. A letter, maybe. Or convincing fiction?

BodyText.SourceString:
It was told to me that his men had all survived the cold and frigid water, but their captain wouldn’t leave the animals behind. He tried to wait out the winter, the fool. 

This captain, as well as the livestock, froze to death. It’s said that when the ice cleared and winter passed, the ship sank to the depths of the ocean. 

One by one, the surviving crew died of pneumonia. Months, even years after they lost the Burgundi, each crew member would fall ill until there were none alive. 

No one would tell me the captain’s true name. Even the thought of it seemed to scare them.

FlavourText.SourceString: The sign is completely caked in snow.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>You try to scrape it away, but you manage to disturb nothing more than a few loose flakes.</>

<RichText.Italic12>The sight of it chills you. Best leave soon or you’ll share the sign’s fate.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: A sign pointing in various directions.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>The top sign reads, "Frostmarch Village 1KM." </>

<RichText.Italic12>Only, there is no town. Nothing more than a name.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: The sign is caked in ice and weathered.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>You can make out the text, "Welcome to Welsford."</>

FlavourText.SourceString: You take a moment to pause and reflect.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>Something about this place leaves you feeling unsettled.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: An old journal lies next to some abandoned bedrolls. It details the frustrations of a deserting soldier.

BodyText.SourceString:
...our legion was called the 'Swords of Maro.' What kind of fuckin’ joke is that? A company of dullards running around calling themselves ‘swords’. 

If Maro were alive to see what a farce his namesake has become, he'd have begged to swallow that bullet.

FlavourText.SourceString: Inside the cave, you are surprised to find an old journal.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>A young highlander spent years searching for the Warden soldiers who slaughtered his family. He details his quest for revenge with alarming clarity. You suspect at some point, he’d drifted into madness. The last entry, in particular, is chilling.</>

I found them. We found them. Buried them, my love. One by one. They told our little boy to smile before they buried that hatchet into his temple. 

I watched. They held my eyes open, made me. Should have killed me. They didn’t. 

We made them smile too before we put them in the ground, didn't we? It wouldn’t do for them to go quickly, oh no . . . No. It wou—

<RichText.Italic12>The rest devolves into illegible scrawlings.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: A letter marked 'Return to Sender' lies on the ground.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>You can tell it's in bad shape, and dare not touch it lest it tear and crumble.</>

To the venerable Alderman Higgins. 

While I understand the construction of your silly wall has caused some amount of stress among the populace. This is of no concern to me. However, I’d implore you to stop sending Warden thugs to my doorstep—they scare my children. 

Whatever your position, don’t presume to intimidate us, the southerners have promised protection, and have thus proven reliable. We will not be moved from our land. We will not be bargained with. 

Make no mistake, it is ours. My family has owned this land for generations, you have no claim to it. 

On this matter, I shall not be swayed. 

Respectfully,

Ava Gibbs.

FlavourText.SourceString: You give yourself a moment to get lost in the hypnotic waves of the Aging Ocean.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>You reflect on the events that lead to this very dock, here on the outskirts of Wyattwick, taking long deep breaths.</>

<RichText.Italic12>The salty ocean breeze refreshes your senses and allows your mind to drift. For the first time in months, you let your hand drop from the pistol on your belt; the one that’s been by your side since you were strong enough to lift it.</>

<RichText.Italic12>Faces of one-time comrades blur and twist in the dark while the crashing surf struggles to drown out all that screaming in the distance. </>

<RichText.Italic12>The crack of nearby gunfire halts your brief reprieve and a sudden sense of dread begins to wash over you.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: You’ve discovered a forgotten letter. It’s marked by a Mesean seal.

BodyText.SourceString:
Consul, there is a great opportunity here that shouldn’t be squandered. 

The peasants south of the wall are angry and in need of an outlet. We should put rifles in their hands and let them march on their oppressors. Let them sow the seeds of mistrust. 

If we establish a holding in the west, imagine what could be accomplished? If my hunch is correct, it would allow us to walk through the gates. The trust of common folk is a powerful tool and they already feel betrayed. 

Our enemy has done half the work.

FlavourText.SourceString: There is a note nailed to the trunk.

BodyText.SourceString:
These trees are no longer to be used for the hanging of criminals. 

Anyone caught doing so will be executed on the spot.

FlavourText.SourceString: The plaque is well-kept and polished.

BodyText.SourceString:
You are a Warden.

You are among the elite.

Sharpen your skills, test your might. 
Strive for glory and lead by example. 

Become a Hand of Callahan and fight back the Colonial menace.

FlavourText.SourceString: Section of a supply report.

BodyText.SourceString:
Resources from offshore states are dwindling, yet our local farms and trades are booming, despite working amidst combat. It's possible, at this juncture, that they are being harassed by Warden partisan forces. 

We know they haven’t the manpower to defend. I suggest requisitioning twice the usual volume and pressure these outliers back into the fold. Send men out to patrol. We’ll need these supplies if we intend to continue our push on the mainland.

FlavourText.SourceString: Vehicles

BodyText.SourceString:
Press ‘Q’ to enter vehicles. 

You must be standing outside the seat you’d like to enter. 

From inside the vehicle you can change seats by pressing ‘ctrl’ + ‘1’ ‘2’ ‘3’ etc. Switching seats doesn’t necessarily work for all seats in every vehicle.

FlavourText.SourceString: Fueling

BodyText.SourceString:
To fuel a vehicle, first refine or acquire diesel or petrol (depending on the vehicle). For training purposes, you can find some in the Storage Box next to the nearby house. 

Press ‘Tab’ to open your inventory and click ‘LMB’ on the fuel to equip it. 

Once equipped, close the menu, approach a vehicle and hold down ‘LMB’ until you are out of fuel.

FlavourText.SourceString: Vehicle Combat

BodyText.SourceString:
Some vehicles have armaments that can be used with your team to wreak havoc on your opponents. 

As a gunner, you must have ammo in your inventory in order to reload with ‘R’. Try using the Armored Car with a partner to get accustomed to the gunner’s position. 

Each vehicle in Foxhole has different functions. If you’re unsure how something works, don’t be afraid to ask.

FlavourText.SourceString: Basic driving controls

BodyText.SourceString:
The driving course is intended to for you to practice basic driving controls. For training purposes, we have provided a selection of vehicles. 

Use "WASD" to control your vehicle just as you move on foot.

Press “Spacebar” for handbrake.

Handle your speed carefully and feather the throttle as you bank into turns. 

There are targets scattered around the course to practice aiming while on in the sidecar of the motorcycle or with the Armored Car. Aiming in a vehicle is also the same. 

In a gunner position/sidecar hold ‘RMB’ to aim and ‘LMB’ to shoot.

FlavourText.SourceString: Vehicle Construction

BodyText.SourceString:
All vehicles are manufactured by players. For training purposes, in the nearby Storage Container, we’ve provided everything you need to build a transport truck. 

Press ‘E’ while inside the Vehicle Factory to open the production menu and select ‘Transport’.

A blueprint will appear. 

With basic materials in your inventory and your hammer equipped (press ‘1’) step up to the blueprint and press ‘LMB’. This will contribute one material to the project. Repeat until the truck is constructed.

FlavourText.SourceString: Artillery Basics

BodyText.SourceString:
When using Artillery, you will have control over heading and distance.

NOTE: Turning requires two players be mounted.

Press Q to mount.

On the right, Use ‘MMB’ to affect distance. On the right, ‘A’ and ‘D’ will change azimuth. 

On the right, when you’re target is confirmed press ‘LMB’ to fire.

There is a catch, you’ll need another player to spot for you, using binoculars. Binoculars don't reach the same distances as the Artillery, so coordination with your spotter is a must in order to get an accurate reading. 

You’ll need a third player to spot for you, using binoculars. 

Binoculars don't reach the same distances as the Artillery, so coordination with your spotter is a must in order to get an accurate reading.

Have your spotter range ahead, and communicate with them to determine whether or not you’ve hit your target.

Binoculars are provided for training in the nearby storage box.

FlavourText.SourceString: Artillery Ammo

BodyText.SourceString:
Artillery Ammo is a Large Object and must be physically carried to your Artillery to reload. 

Press “LMB” to reload when standing near your Artillery.

You’ll know you’re close enough when the prompt appears in the bottom left.

Artillery shells are provided in the nearby storage box.

FlavourText.SourceString: Basic Scrapping

BodyText.SourceString:
Resources are used to manufacture everything, from ammunition to medical supplies and tanks.

Equip your Hammer and use ‘LMB’ on scrap piles. Harvesters can also be used to procure resources. Components and Sulfur require a Sledgehammer to gather which have been provided in a Storage Box nearby.

Each item requires different materials to manufacture, but must first be refined.

Try gathering some materials—which can be found ahead—loading them in one of the trucks provided then bringing them over to the refinery next to you.

There you’ll also find a factory where you can make use of some of your newly refined materials.

FlavourText.SourceString: Upgrade Parts

BodyText.SourceString:
Occasionally, you will discover Upgrade Parts while mining resources. 

Upgrade Parts can be used to upgrade the facilities of various structures.

For a more detailed explanation click the “?” icon in the top right corner of the Town Hall menu.

FlavourText.SourceString: Refinery

BodyText.SourceString:
The Refinery will convert scrap and other raw resources into materials which can be used to produce items, vehicles, and structures. 

For a more detailed explanation click the “?” icon in the top right corner of the Refinery menu.

FlavourText.SourceString: Factory

BodyText.SourceString:
Factories are used to manufacture various items. 

Feel free to use the factory nearby. 

If you need resources, try refining materials which can be gathered at one of the various nodes on the island. 

For a more detailed explanation click the “?” icon in the top right corner of the Factory menu.

FlavourText.SourceString: Building

BodyText.SourceString:
Press ‘B’ with a hammer equipped to open the build menu.

After selecting structure, a blueprint will appear at your mouse pointer. 

Hold ‘RMB’ while moving your mouse to rotate the blueprint, and "LMB" to place the blueprint.

Once placed, use ‘LMB’ with your hammer to deposit materials until structure is complete. 

Try building a Foxhole in the dirt in front of you. 

Multiple soldiers can collaborate on building any given blueprint. 

Some surfaces, such as the gravel behind you, or sand, may not be suitable for building.

FlavourText.SourceString: Storage Facility

BodyText.SourceString:
The Storage Facility is, as its name implies, a structure for storing items and vehicles for later use. 

You can submit crates of items, vehicles or storage containers. 

For a more detailed explanation click the '?' icon in the top right corner of the Storage Facility menu.

FlavourText.SourceString: Construction Yard

BodyText.SourceString:
The Construction Yard is used to build Shipping Containers. 

Shipping Containers can be filled with items and moved long distances using a flatbed truck. 

To move shipping containers they first must be packaged, and then transported short distances with a crane.

FlavourText.SourceString: Logistics Training

BodyText.SourceString:
Welcome to basic logisitcal training. 

Here you’ll be able to interact with various structures in the game. 

Press ‘E’ to interact with every structure. This will open their unique menu as well as their inventory. 

If you are confused as to how to use a structure, click on the '?' in the top right corner of the menu pane for more information. Don’t be afraid to ask around!

FlavourText.SourceString: Mines

BodyText.SourceString:
Resources can also be acquired through mining.

Mines require fuel to operate and will automatically generate resources over time. 

Which type of fuel you use determines the mine’s effeciency. 

For training purposes, fuel has been provided in a Storage Box nearby. 

For more information, click on the ‘?’ icon in the corner of the Mine menu.

FlavourText.SourceString: Fuel

BodyText.SourceString:
Fuel can be acquired in two ways. 

First, you can refine scrap into Diesel.

Second, using Diesel to fuel Oil Wells, which will produce Oil Barrels. Barrels can then be refined into Petrol. 

Petrol can also be used to produce Barrels at a higher efficency.

FlavourText.SourceString: Basic Training

BodyText.SourceString:
Welcome to basic training. 

Here you can practice the various basic tools needed to be successful on the front line. 

Follow the course ahead to get started. Signs along the way will explain basic controls and functionality.

If you have questions about anything, don’t be afraid to ask in chat.

FlavourText.SourceString: Basic Controls

BodyText.SourceString:
Press ‘Shift’ to sprint. 

If you get lost, open the map with ‘M’. While in the map screen, zoom with the 'Mouse Wheel' and click to drag the map around.

FlavourText.SourceString: Camera

BodyText.SourceString: To rotate the camera, hold ‘MMB’ while moving the mouse left and right.

FlavourText.SourceString: Setting Your Spawn

BodyText.SourceString:
Before continuing your training, make sure to set your spawn point at the Forward Base ahead. 

Press ‘E’ to interact with the Base. Here you’ll see its inventory and various options to upgrade/manage the base. Ignore those for now

Click the flashing ‘house’ icon that reads, ‘Assign spawn point.’

For more information, click on the ‘?’ icon in the corner of the Outpost menu.

FlavourText.SourceString: Soldier Supplies

BodyText.SourceString:
Make sure you load the Forward Base with soldier supplies. 

For training purposes, you can find some in these Storage Crates. 

You can open containers by pressing ‘E’.

‘LMB’ to pull a single item, ‘SHIFT+LMB’ to pull the entire stack.

‘RMB’ opens a context menu.

‘CTRL’ + ‘LMB’ to split a stack in half.

‘ALT’ + ‘LMB’ to drop the item.

These are the same controls for putting items from your backpack into another structure or container, which you’ll need to do with these soldier supplies in the Forward Base ahead.

FlavourText.SourceString: Vaulting

BodyText.SourceString: Press ‘Space’ to vault over low cover, such as sandbags or to climb small fences and walls.

FlavourText.SourceString: Ladders

BodyText.SourceString:
Just like vaulting, press ‘Space’ to mount a ladder. 

Press ‘W’ or ‘A’ to move up or down.

FlavourText.SourceString: Weapons

BodyText.SourceString:
Firearms are an unfortunate necessity on the front line. 

For training purposes, a variety of firearms have been provided in the nearby Storage Containers.

Normally, all weapons must be manufactured.

To assign a weapon to its corresponding slot, open your inventory with ‘TAB’ and click the desired weapon. 

Once assigned, close your backpack and equip the weapon with ‘1’ if it is a primary or ‘2’ if it is a secondary. 

Aim by holding ‘RMB’ and fire using ‘LMB’.

Try practicing on these targets.

FlavourText.SourceString: Gun Range

BodyText.SourceString:
Welcome to the Gun Range. 

Here you can practice the fundamentals of gunplay and combat.

FlavourText.SourceString: Grenades

BodyText.SourceString:
Grenades are equipped from your inventory, just like any other weapon, into the tertiary weapon slot. 

Equip with ‘3’.

Grenades are thrown in an arc, which you can visualise while aiming with ‘RMB’. 

Hold ‘LMB’ to cook your grenade, and release when ready to throw.

FlavourText.SourceString: Ammo

BodyText.SourceString:
Ammo is sectioned off into individual magazines. 

Be careful not to carry too many, it can get heavy and, if you’re not paying attention, wasteful. 

Once you reload with ‘R’, you discard your old magazine, so only reload when absolutely necessary.

FlavourText.SourceString: Stability

BodyText.SourceString:
Keep an eye on your crosshairs. When they’re close together, you have a much greater chance of hitting your target. 

Every shot will reduce stability.

There are three ways to increase stability. 

One, standing still while firing.

Two, crouching with ‘C’.

Three, going prone with ‘X’

Being prone gives you the greatest stability, but at the cost of mobility.

FlavourText.SourceString: Stances

BodyText.SourceString:
Change stances into a crouch ‘C’ or prone ‘X’ to reduce your profile and increase stability. 

Practice moving while crouched or prone in the course ahead.

FlavourText.SourceString: Medical

BodyText.SourceString:
There are three types of Medical gear.

Apply Bandages to yourself to stop bleeding. The bandage is consumed. 

First Aid Kits heal wounds and require bandages. 

Trauma Kits heal critical wounds and require Blood Plasma.

Equip and use them as you would a weapon.

Trauma Kits and First Aid Kits can only be used on other soldiers.

To help a Wounded comrade when you have no supplies, holster your weapon, hold ‘LMB’ to help stem the wounds until a medic swings by.

Critically Wounded soldiers can be picked up with “E” then loaded onto an ambulance or treated at a Hospital or Field Hospital.

FlavourText.SourceString: Test Course

BodyText.SourceString:
This course is designed to test you.

Grab a friend and ask them to shoot at you while you move from cover to cover. Take shots at them along the way. 

See if you can hit all the targets as you make your way through.

FlavourText.SourceString: Visibility

BodyText.SourceString:
Visibility is an important consideration when navigating the battlefield. 

Anything your character can't see, will become invisible on screen. 

Hiding in grass, behind walls, and bushes are all useful options for a stealthy approach. Moving while hidden will expose you and if you are hiding near an enemy soldier in the same bush, or inside smoke, you may still be able to see one another. 

Try testing the results with other soldiers in the grass ahead.

FlavourText.SourceString: Swimming

BodyText.SourceString:
With all that gear, swimming is difficult and takes tons of energy. 

You can't make it very far without drowning so watch your stamina. Once it runs out, you will die. 

With full stamina, try to swim to the ladders on the opposite side, and press ‘Space’ to climb up to the dock.

FlavourText.SourceString: Cover

BodyText.SourceString:
On top of providing protection, using cover will give you a boost to stability. 

Keep an eye on the shield at the bottom of the screen. Depending on how deep in cover you are will determine the boost.

If you are fired on, you will eventually become Suppressed, which will reduce and eventually negate the stability boost.

Being suppressed out in the open will negatively impact your stability.

Test out cover on the different parts of the wall in front of you.

FlavourText.SourceString: Trench Basics

BodyText.SourceString:
To start a trench, first you need a shovel. Find some in one of the nearby storage containers. 

With a shovel equipped, press ‘B’ to open the build menu.

Make your selection and, when starting a new trench, place the plot like any other structure. 

Once you’ve placed a plot, hold ‘LMB’ to dig. 

This will take some time, but digging trenches is easier with a crew.

FlavourText.SourceString: Snapping Trenches

BodyText.SourceString:
Once you have an initial Trench or Bunker in place, further trenches or bunkers will snap to different sections. 

Try stapping new trenches to the different sides of the initial one. 

To make a “T” shaped trench, rotate your blueprint on the long-side of a trench. 

Connect new bunkers by simply snapping new sections.

Trenches can be extended from Bunkers as well. 

Hold “Shift” to break snapping.

Separate trench lines can be connected using a Trench Connector.

FlavourText.SourceString: Upgrading and Modifying Trenches

BodyText.SourceString:
First, build a fresh Trench and attach a Bunker.

Equip a hammer, then walk up to the Bunker. Facing the wall, press ‘E’. 

You should see a menu with new options.

You can upgrade your Bunker in a variety of different ways. Convert it into AI defenses, add firing ports, or a variety of other useful tools.

To enter upgrade mode, with the Hammer equipped, press ‘F’. A ‘Hammer’ icon indicates over a structure indicates which structure you will be upgrading. Press ‘E’ to open the upgrade menu.

Trenches and Bunkers can be enhanced with reinforced wood, or eventually, Concrete.

Grab some materials from the storage container nearby. Add a door to the Bunker and upgrade your trenches to tier 2.

HintText.SourceString: read about Upgrading and Modifying Trenches

FlavourText.SourceString: Power, Pipes and Concrete.

BodyText.SourceString:
In order to make better use of your trenches, you will need to upgrade them to tier 3 or “Concrete” trenches. 

This requires a Concrete mixer, which must first be built at the Construction Yard. 

In order to power Bunker defences, you will need an Engine Room.

Engine Rooms require concrete Bunkers. 

You then must build pipes to support the desired structure.

HintText.SourceString: read about Power, Pipes and Concrete.

FlavourText.SourceString: Basic watercraft controls

BodyText.SourceString:
For training purposes, various watercraft have been provided for you to  practice basic driving controls and functionality. 

Use "WASD" to control your vehicle just as you move on foot.

HeaderText.SourceString: A Personal Treatise on the Impact of the Hanged Men

FlavourText.SourceString: There are scattered pages from a newly written manuscript.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>The name "Tobias Zephyr" is signed on the title page.</>

<RichText.Italic12>You leaf through the treatise and stop, skimming over a few paragraphs.</>

Though the vaults were first discovered by sycophants and scheming thieves, exposing the inner workings of the vaults and allowing us access to relics of old has had its advantages. It is no surprise that many schematics and blueprints had become unfortunate victims in the various raids on our plants in the south. The engineers did what they could, but a mere imitation will always be just that, a second-rate copy. 

Now through reverse engineering these beasts, new schematics have been drawn up, and we do believe we can manufacture a suitable replacement alloy for those no longer in abundance. What is more, various improvements to the overall structure, and we have made many modernizations. Such are the insights of these discoveries that we believe some rediscovered processes may yet make their way back into our modern arsenal.

The Hanged men, the greedy bastards, have done us an extraordinary service in hoarding the past—Colonial and Warden both—behind their mountainous vaults. It is a damn shame we had not discovered them sooner. In consequence, more intel on Warden manufacturing has landed in our lap, details behind the superb structural engineering use on the vaults themselves, and we have reclaimed a piece of our history. 

The Magisters will be all too eager to study these schematics and their impact on the war effort. I dispatched copies by courier to Alympia College. Though Paeon would like to see their order abolished, I have found the Magisters to be quite helpful in my time on the council. In truth, it is a shame more are not trained. Mayhaps we would have fewer scoundrels. It is a foolish thought; the classless are like rats: stamp one out, and a dozen more take their place. 

Forgive these digressions; they are the ramblings of an old, optimistic fool. Now, onto matters concerning the identities of the Hanged Men . .

HeaderText.SourceString: Letter From the Office of the Archon

FlavourText.SourceString: A stack of letters from various parts of alliance territory rest on the table.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>Return addresses from Nicnevin, Whedon’s Row, Sorovia, while some come from as far west as Wenitai.</>

<RichText.Italic12>You open a letter from Whedon’s Row.</>

From the office of the Archon. 

Judith Abell,

These pirates must be dealt with. It’s bad enough that such sensitive Warden intel has leaked, but now we’re dealing with gutless cowards too. Did you know they’re mostly deserters, the Hanged Men? I’d like to get a noose around their necks myself. 

Now I’m hearing that you’re tearing apart our arsenal and fitting them with . . . with what? It seems like a buffoonish vanity project to me. The Archon is not pleased and expects a full report explaining why resources have been spent on nonsense. It would behoove you to act quickly, lest he sends the Hands. Were it a Callahan in the chair, you might have your requests placated, but alas. 

Stop acting impetuously, Judith, or you will forfeit your position. There are plenty of sharks in the sea.

FlavourText.SourceString: In passing, you notice a set of schematics with various notes pinned to the stack.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>Among the notes are instructions for refitting new parts onto the chassis of a simple truck directed at an individual mechanic.</>

It’s not ideal to entirely replace the axle, though you may think it necessary. We’ve built adapters that work with the existing axles so that when you fit the new part, the leverage is sound.

<RichText.Italic12>There’s a crude drawing of how the adapter fits with several scribble arrows.</>

Now, as for how we plan to maximize space in the wagon? They’re built to come off peacefully. Then we can haul in a whole new fitting. Whatever the engineers want to try. It’s easy stuff, but worth noting that the chassis can only handle so much weight, so tell the guys to give’r a test before going all out. 

Pete, if anyone bothers you about this, tell ‘em to talk to Ms. Abell. It’s her project. Don’t argue if they demand you stop, just get her out here, and she’ll clear it up. No one wants to see your guys get shot.

FlavourText.SourceString: A collection of mechanical parts are strewn about the ground.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>Picking through them, you notice a few you don’t recognize. They seem like they may fit current armour, but in ways which you’re unsure.</>

<RichText.Italic12>You lift a pipe and read the inscription on the side.</>

H5-Beta Vulcan

<RichText.Italic12>It has a curious fitting on one end, with large bolts and oddly shaped washers.</>

<RichText.Italic12>You toss it back into the pile and go about your day.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: You find a letter marked as having been sent from Tempest Island.

BodyText.SourceString:
Dear Mr. Wellington,

We’ve gone through the tests. There have been significant findings. Significant indeed. The stones, let’s call them “geistglass” for the sake of reference, are indeed fungal in nature though, the specifics of how a stonelike object reproduces are still a mystery. The geistglass reproductive process happens underground; thus, it is difficult to monitor. 

Our experiments in breaching the underworld have been most conclusive, indeed. We’ve managed to summon forth a tear of sorts. All the men who’ve monitored the tear have subsequently gone mad, rambling on about evil eyes or some such nonsense. Strangely, these men seem to snap out of their madness once removed some distance from the tears. 

These . . . tears or, perhaps more accurately, fonts, require a not-insignificant amount of geistglass to stabilize. We’ve experimented with the geistglass along with various methods of reaching into the other side of the fonts. Small fragments of geistglass can be used as a conduit to entrap these accursed demons that storm through during the harvest moon.

There’s more work to be done, but there may be a way to make use of this information. Instead of simply unleashing the dead on the southerners, perhaps we can harness that rage. 

When I’m back on the mainland, we’ll creak open that bottle of Sorovian vodka.
- Miles.

FlavourText.SourceString: You’ve stumbled upon what appears to be the final scrawlings of an unlucky worker. The letters are erratic and scratchy, and a spattering of blood stains the edge of the paper.

BodyText.SourceString:
Oh, stars, what have we done. We’ve taken it too far, dug too deep. Whoever finds this, don’t go deeper. 

We weren’t clever. We weren’t smart. They’re the architects, not us. They— 

<RichText.Italic12>The words trail off, becoming lost in the crimson stain.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: There’s a coded telegram written in small strange symbols. The code has been deciphered underneath.

BodyText.SourceString:
This land is cursed. Instead of an attempt to harness this . . . darkness, we should erase it from the map.

Our Tempest Island insurgents are issuing reports of Wardens having made significant progress in weaponizing the cursed.

We must now choose. Engage or demolish. Perhaps we need to bring the Centurion out of retirement?

FlavourText.SourceString: An old-looking typewriter. For some reason, you have an urge to write about your day.

BodyText.SourceString: <RichText.Italic12>Unfortunately, you're still out of ink ribbons.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: You reflect on how you’ve managed to survive.

BodyText.SourceString:
<RichText.Italic12>It’s been three years since the accords, you think. Somehow, you’ve survived against countless odds, numerous betrayals and assaults against your character, your integrity, and your flesh. </>

<RichText.Italic12>You remember the first stand against the cursed undead; you remember fleeing the island by boat while it was overrun. You remember former enemies standing side by side to fight a greater threat. When the great Centurion was deployed against the dead—a combination of Warden and Colonial engineering, the first of its kind—you recall standing by, awed at its ability to drive the dead back to the grave.</>

<RichText.Italic12>How had things fallen apart? you ponder. </>

<RichText.Italic12>The town seems different than it once had, but still so familiar—the past flashes behind your eyes. The old church has been repaired, mostly. Only remnants of the stand remain. It’s funny how little has changed in reality. Must we go on fighting? you question, not seeking closure.</>

<RichText.Italic12>For you know the answer, and it’s not in your favour.</>

FlavourText.SourceString: In Flanders Fields by John McRae.

BodyText.SourceString:
In Flanders fields the poppies blow
Between the crosses, row on row,
    That mark our place; and in the sky
    The larks, still bravely singing, fly
Scarce heard amid the guns below.

We are the Dead. Short days ago
We lived, felt dawn, saw sunset glow,
    Loved and were loved, and now we lie,
        In Flanders fields.

Take up our quarrel with the foe:
To you from failing hands we throw
    The torch; be yours to hold it high.
    If ye break faith with us who die
We shall not sleep, though poppies grow
        In Flanders fields.

FlavourText.SourceString: Field Artillery

BodyText.SourceString:
Field Artillery works largely the same as Emplaced Artillery

Refer to Artillery Basics tutorial for specifics.

The main difference is that Field Artillery can be manually moved when two players are mounted.

Field Artillery will not have as much range and power, but makes up for it in mobility.

FlavourText.SourceString: Artillery and Wind

BodyText.SourceString:
Artillery and all indirect-fire weapons are affected by wind.

The power and direction of the wind will affect the trajectory and dispersion of each shot.

You can determine the wind’s direction by ‘standing flags’ on structures, such as the nearby radio towers. 

How aggressively the flag flaps indicates how strong the wind is at any given moment.

Test firing can be important for determining the current impact of wind on your bombardments.
